list.comment: Did the first of the "Advent of Code" puzzles and really enjoyed it. Refined it to the point of elegance, for practice.

changelist.name: Changes
changelist.comment: Finally figured out how to reconcile the problems I had between my handling of GITHUB in PyCharm and in the browser. Began the process of getting this organized into more of a portfolio.

task.summary: Did substantial work on the chord suggester. Have now generated three (pretty cool) progressions to play with. Spent a ton of time experimenting with predicting key signatures based strictly on chord progressions. Reached 10/12 success (employing an established algorithm) but wound up going another direction with the chord suggester. Namely, getting key signature info from the internet. Useful learning experiences.

Did substantial work on the chord suggester. Have now generated three (pretty cool) progressions to play with. Spent a ton of time experimenting with predicting key signatures based strictly on chord progressions. Reached 10/12 success (employing an established algorithm) but wound up going another direction with the chord suggester. Namely, getting key signature info from the internet. Useful learning experiences.

Been playing with a lyric generator that lets you provide the rhythm (/--/--/-) and gives you random options that are common, uncommon, and rare. Writes a poetry that, while usually nonsensical, is not hideous. XD

Created Player and Triple class for a highly hypothetical game, but it was a good learning experience. I wanted a different sort of stats system, where a character is not, say, a fighter or a cleric or a mage, but is some point on the Venn diagram of the three. I created the Triple class to make objects for each of the stats in a player. The real trick turned out to be accommodating numbers that don't total 100, but it was a fun challenge. If you enter 1 part elf, 2 parts dwarf, 3 parts orc, it does the math and gives you numbers that total 100. Pleased with this.
Did the first in series of jobs/microprojects, this one cleaning the data in a csv using pandas--standardized names and dates and validating email addresses.
Made the basic "daily seeds" project, with absolutely zero perks. :) Gives random prompts for writing, music, and coding.
Made a very simple randomizer for my "voltage" character interaction method.
Did the first of the "Advent of Code" puzzles and really enjoyed it. Refined it to the point of elegance, for practice.
